cards.term: alarm reaction
cards.definition: first stage of the general adaptation syndrome; characterized as the body's immediate physiological reaction to a threatening situation or some other emergency; analogous to the fight-or-flight response

cards.term: first stage of the general adaptation syndrome; characterized as the body's immediate physiological reaction to a threatening situation or some other emergency; analogous to the fight-or-flight response
cards.definition: alarm reaction

cards.term: asthma
cards.definition: psychophysiological disorder in which the airways of the respiratory system become obstructed, leading to great difficulty expelling air from the lungs

cards.term: psychophysiological disorder in which the airways of the respiratory system become obstructed, leading to great difficulty expelling air from the lungs
cards.definition: asthma

cards.term: biofeedback
cards.definition: stress-reduction technique using electronic equipment to measure a person's involuntary (neuromuscular and autonomic) activity and provide feedback to help the person gain a level of voluntary control over these processes

cards.term: stress-reduction technique using electronic equipment to measure a person's involuntary (neuromuscular and autonomic) activity and provide feedback to help the person gain a level of voluntary control over these processes
cards.definition: biofeedback

cards.term: cardiovascular disorders
cards.definition: disorders that involve the heart and blood circulation system

cards.term: disorders that involve the heart and blood circulation system
cards.definition: cardiovascular disorders

cards.term: coping
cards.definition: mental or behavioral efforts used to manage problems relating to stress, including its cause and the unpleasant feelings and emotions it produces

cards.term: mental or behavioral efforts used to manage problems relating to stress, including its cause and the unpleasant feelings and emotions it produces
cards.definition: coping

cards.term: cortisol
cards.definition: stress hormone released by the adrenal glands when encountering a stressor; helps to provide a boost of energy, thereby preparing the individual to take action

cards.term: stress hormone released by the adrenal glands when encountering a stressor; helps to provide a boost of energy, thereby preparing the individual to take action
cards.definition: cortisol

cards.term: daily hassles
cards.definition: minor irritations and annoyances that are part of our everyday lives and are capable of producing stress

cards.term: minor irritations and annoyances that are part of our everyday lives and are capable of producing stress
cards.definition: daily hassles

cards.term: distress
cards.definition: bad form of stress; usually high in intensity; often leads to exhaustion, fatigue, feeling burned out; associated with erosions in performance and health

cards.term: bad form of stress; usually high in intensity; often leads to exhaustion, fatigue, feeling burned out; associated with erosions in performance and health
cards.definition: distress

cards.term: eustress
cards.definition: good form of stress; low to moderate in intensity; associated with positive feelings, as well as optimal health and performance

cards.term: good form of stress; low to moderate in intensity; associated with positive feelings, as well as optimal health and performance
cards.definition: eustress

cards.term: fight-or-flight response
cards.definition: set of physiological reactions (increases in blood pressure, heart rate, respiration rate, and sweat) that occur when an individual encounters a perceived threat; these reactions are produced by activation of the sympathetic nervous system and the endocrine system

cards.term: set of physiological reactions (increases in blood pressure, heart rate, respiration rate, and sweat) that occur when an individual encounters a perceived threat; these reactions are produced by activation of the sympathetic nervous system and the endocrine system
cards.definition: fight-or-flight response

cards.term: flow
cards.definition: state involving intense engagement in an activity; usually is experienced when participating in creative, work, and leisure endeavors

cards.term: state involving intense engagement in an activity; usually is experienced when participating in creative, work, and leisure endeavors
cards.definition: flow

cards.term: general adaptation syndrome
cards.definition: Hans Selye's three-stage model of the body's physiological reactions to stress and the process of stress adaptation: alarm reaction, stage of resistance, and stage of exhaustion

cards.term: Hans Selye's three-stage model of the body's physiological reactions to stress and the process of stress adaptation: alarm reaction, stage of resistance, and stage of exhaustion
cards.definition: general adaptation syndrome

cards.term: happiness
cards.definition: enduring state of mind consisting of joy, contentment, and other positive emotions; the sense that one's life has meaning and value

cards.term: enduring state of mind consisting of joy, contentment, and other positive emotions; the sense that one's life has meaning and value
cards.definition: happiness

cards.term: health psychology
cards.definition: subfield of psychology devoted to studying psychological influences on health, illness, and how people respond when they become ill

cards.term: subfield of psychology devoted to studying psychological influences on health, illness, and how people respond when they become ill
cards.definition: health psychology

cards.term: heart disease
cards.definition: several types of adverse heart conditions, including those that involve the heart's arteries or valves or those involving the inability of the heart to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs; can include heart attack and stroke

cards.term: several types of adverse heart conditions, including those that involve the heart's arteries or valves or those involving the inability of the heart to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs; can include heart attack and stroke
cards.definition: heart disease

cards.term: hypertension
cards.definition: high blood pressure

cards.term: high blood pressure
cards.definition: hypertension

cards.term: hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis
cards.definition: set of structures found in both the limbic system (hypothalamus) and the endocrine system (pituitary gland and adrenal glands) that regulate many of the body's physiological reactions to stress through the release of hormones

cards.term: set of structures found in both the limbic system (hypothalamus) and the endocrine system (pituitary gland and adrenal glands) that regulate many of the body's physiological reactions to stress through the release of hormones
cards.definition: hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis

cards.term: immune system
cards.definition: various structures, cells, and mechanisms that protect the body from foreign substances that can damage the body's tissues and organs

cards.term: various structures, cells, and mechanisms that protect the body from foreign substances that can damage the body's tissues and organs
cards.definition: immune system

cards.term: immunosuppression
cards.definition: decreased effectiveness of the immune system

cards.term: decreased effectiveness of the immune system
cards.definition: immunosuppression

cards.term: job burnout
cards.definition: general sense of emotional exhaustion and cynicism in relation to one's job; consists of three dimensions: exhaustion, depersonalization, and sense of diminished personal accomplishment

cards.term: general sense of emotional exhaustion and cynicism in relation to one's job; consists of three dimensions: exhaustion, depersonalization, and sense of diminished personal accomplishment
cards.definition: job burnout

cards.term: job strain
cards.definition: work situation involving the combination of excessive job demands and workload with little decision making latitude or job control

cards.term: work situation involving the combination of excessive job demands and workload with little decision making latitude or job control
cards.definition: job strain

cards.term: lymphocytes
cards.definition: white blood cells that circulate in the body's fluids and are especially important in the body's immune response

cards.term: white blood cells that circulate in the body's fluids and are especially important in the body's immune response
cards.definition: lymphocytes

cards.term: negative affectivity
cards.definition: tendency to experience distressed emotional states involving anger, contempt, disgust, guilt, fear, and nervousness

cards.term: tendency to experience distressed emotional states involving anger, contempt, disgust, guilt, fear, and nervousness
cards.definition: negative affectivity

cards.term: optimism
cards.definition: tendency toward a positive outlook and positive expectations

cards.term: tendency toward a positive outlook and positive expectations
cards.definition: optimism

cards.term: perceived control
cards.definition: peoples' beliefs concerning their capacity to influence and shape outcomes in their lives

cards.term: peoples' beliefs concerning their capacity to influence and shape outcomes in their lives
cards.definition: perceived control

cards.term: positive affect
cards.definition: state or a trait that involves pleasurable engagement with the environment, the dimensions of which include happiness, joy, enthusiasm, alertness, and excitement

cards.term: state or a trait that involves pleasurable engagement with the environment, the dimensions of which include happiness, joy, enthusiasm, alertness, and excitement
cards.definition: positive affect

cards.term: positive psychology
cards.definition: scientific area of study seeking to identify and promote those qualities that lead to happy, fulfilled, and contented lives

cards.term: scientific area of study seeking to identify and promote those qualities that lead to happy, fulfilled, and contented lives
cards.definition: positive psychology

cards.term: primary appraisal
cards.definition: judgment about the degree of potential harm or threat to well-being that a stressor might entail

cards.term: judgment about the degree of potential harm or threat to well-being that a stressor might entail
cards.definition: primary appraisal

cards.term: psychoneuroimmunology
cards.definition: field that studies how psychological factors (such as stress) influence the immune system and immune functioning

cards.term: field that studies how psychological factors (such as stress) influence the immune system and immune functioning
cards.definition: psychoneuroimmunology

cards.term: psychophysiological disorders
cards.definition: physical disorders or diseases in which symptoms are brought about or worsened by stress and emotional factors

cards.term: physical disorders or diseases in which symptoms are brought about or worsened by stress and emotional factors
cards.definition: psychophysiological disorders

cards.term: relaxation response technique
cards.definition: stress reduction technique combining elements of relaxation and meditation

cards.term: stress reduction technique combining elements of relaxation and meditation
cards.definition: relaxation response technique

cards.term: secondary appraisal
cards.definition: judgment of options available to cope with a stressor and their potential effectiveness

cards.term: judgment of options available to cope with a stressor and their potential effectiveness
cards.definition: secondary appraisal

cards.term: Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS)
cards.definition: popular scale designed to measure stress; consists of 43 potentially stressful events, each of which has a numerical value quantifying how much readjustment is associated with the event

cards.term: popular scale designed to measure stress; consists of 43 potentially stressful events, each of which has a numerical value quantifying how much readjustment is associated with the event
cards.definition: Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS)

cards.term: social support
cards.definition: soothing and often beneficial support of others; can take different forms, such as advice, guidance, encouragement, acceptance, emotional comfort, and tangible assistance

cards.term: soothing and often beneficial support of others; can take different forms, such as advice, guidance, encouragement, acceptance, emotional comfort, and tangible assistance
cards.definition: social support

cards.term: stage of exhaustion
cards.definition: third stage of the general adaptation syndrome; the body's ability to resist stress becomes depleted; illness, disease, and even death may occur

cards.term: third stage of the general adaptation syndrome; the body's ability to resist stress becomes depleted; illness, disease, and even death may occur
cards.definition: stage of exhaustion

cards.term: stage of resistance
cards.definition: second stage of the general adaptation syndrome; the body adapts to a stressor for a period of time

cards.term: second stage of the general adaptation syndrome; the body adapts to a stressor for a period of time
cards.definition: stage of resistance

cards.term: stress
cards.definition: process whereby an individual perceives and responds to events that one appraises as overwhelming or threatening to one's well-being

cards.term: process whereby an individual perceives and responds to events that one appraises as overwhelming or threatening to one's well-being
cards.definition: stress

cards.term: stressors
cards.definition: environmental events that may be judged as threatening or demanding; stimuli that initiate the stress process

cards.term: environmental events that may be judged as threatening or demanding; stimuli that initiate the stress process
cards.definition: stressors

cards.term: Type A
cards.definition: psychological and behavior pattern exhibited by individuals who tend to be extremely competitive, impatient, rushed, and hostile toward others

cards.term: psychological and behavior pattern exhibited by individuals who tend to be extremely competitive, impatient, rushed, and hostile toward others
cards.definition: Type A

cards.term: Type B
cards.definition: psychological and behavior pattern exhibited by a person who is relaxed and laid back

cards.term: psychological and behavior pattern exhibited by a person who is relaxed and laid back
cards.definition: Type B

cards.term: Negative effects of stress are most likely to be experienced when an event is perceived as ________.
cards.definition: Threatening, and no clear options for dealing with it are apparent

cards.term: Threatening, and no clear options for dealing with it are apparent
cards.definition: Negative effects of stress are most likely to be experienced when an event is perceived as ________.

cards.term: Between 2006 and 2009, the greatest increases in stress levels were found to occur among ________.
cards.definition: Those aged 45-64

cards.term: Those aged 45-64
cards.definition: Between 2006 and 2009, the greatest increases in stress levels were found to occur among ________.

cards.term: At which stage of Selye's general adaptation syndrome is a person especially vulnerable to illness?
cards.definition: Exhaustion

cards.term: Exhaustion
cards.definition: At which stage of Selye's general adaptation syndrome is a person especially vulnerable to illness?

cards.term: During an encounter judged as stressful, cortisol is released by the ________.
cards.definition: Adrenal glands

cards.term: Adrenal glands
cards.definition: During an encounter judged as stressful, cortisol is released by the ________.

cards.term: According to the Holmes and Rahe scale, which life event requires the greatest amount of readjustment?
cards.definition: Death of spouse

cards.term: Death of spouse
cards.definition: According to the Holmes and Rahe scale, which life event requires the greatest amount of readjustment?

cards.term: While waiting to pay for his weekly groceries at the supermarket, Paul had to wait... These events that Paul had to endure are best characterized as ________.
cards.definition: Daily hassles

cards.term: Daily hassles
cards.definition: While waiting to pay for his weekly groceries at the supermarket, Paul had to wait... These events that Paul had to endure are best characterized as ________.

cards.term: What is one of the major criticisms of the Social Readjustment Rating Scale?
cards.definition: It does not take into consideration how a person appraises an event

cards.term: It does not take into consideration how a person appraises an event
cards.definition: What is one of the major criticisms of the Social Readjustment Rating Scale?

cards.term: Which of the following is not a dimension of job burnout?
cards.definition: Hostility

cards.term: Hostility
cards.definition: Which of the following is not a dimension of job burnout?

cards.term: The white blood cells that attack foreign invaders to the body are called ________.
cards.definition: Lymphocytes

cards.term: Lymphocytes
cards.definition: The white blood cells that attack foreign invaders to the body are called ________.

cards.term: The risk of heart disease is especially high among individuals with ________.
cards.definition: Depression

cards.term: Depression
cards.definition: The risk of heart disease is especially high among individuals with ________.

cards.term: The most lethal dimension of Type A behavior pattern seems to be ________.
cards.definition: Hostility

cards.term: Hostility
cards.definition: The most lethal dimension of Type A behavior pattern seems to be ________.

cards.term: Which of the following statements pertaining to asthma is false?
cards.definition: Rates of asthma have decreased considerably since 2000

cards.term: Rates of asthma have decreased considerably since 2000
cards.definition: Which of the following statements pertaining to asthma is false?

cards.term: Emotion-focused coping would likely be a better method than problem-focused coping for dealing with which of the following stressors?
cards.definition: Terminal cancer

cards.term: Terminal cancer
cards.definition: Emotion-focused coping would likely be a better method than problem-focused coping for dealing with which of the following stressors?

cards.term: Studies of British civil servants have found that those in the lowest status jobs are much more likely to develop heart disease... These findings attest to the importance of ________ in dealing with stress.
cards.definition: Perceived control

cards.term: Perceived control
cards.definition: Studies of British civil servants have found that those in the lowest status jobs are much more likely to develop heart disease... These findings attest to the importance of ________ in dealing with stress.

cards.term: Relative to those with low levels of social support, individuals with high levels of social support ________.
cards.definition: Tend to tolerate stress well

cards.term: Tend to tolerate stress well
cards.definition: Relative to those with low levels of social support, individuals with high levels of social support ________.

cards.term: The concept of learned helplessness was formulated by Seligman to explain the ________.
cards.definition: Inability of dogs to attempt to escape avoidable shocks after having received inescapable shocks

cards.term: Inability of dogs to attempt to escape avoidable shocks after having received inescapable shocks
cards.definition: The concept of learned helplessness was formulated by Seligman to explain the ________.

cards.term: Which of the following is not one of the presumed components of happiness?
cards.definition: Learning new skills

cards.term: Learning new skills
cards.definition: Which of the following is not one of the presumed components of happiness?

cards.term: Researchers have identified a number of factors that are related to happiness. Which of the following is not one of them?
cards.definition: Physical attractiveness

cards.term: Physical attractiveness
cards.definition: Researchers have identified a number of factors that are related to happiness. Which of the following is not one of them?

cards.term: How does positive affect differ from optimism?
cards.definition: Positive affect involves feeling states, whereas optimism involves expectations

cards.term: Positive affect involves feeling states, whereas optimism involves expectations
cards.definition: How does positive affect differ from optimism?

cards.term: Carson enjoys writing mystery novels... Carson's experience best illustrates the concept of ________.
cards.definition: Flow

cards.term: Flow
cards.definition: Carson enjoys writing mystery novels... Carson's experience best illustrates the concept of ________.

cards.term: Stimulus-Based Definition of Stress
cards.definition: Conceptualizes stress as a demanding or threatening event/situation (the stressor itself).

cards.term: Conceptualizes stress as a demanding or threatening event/situation (the stressor itself).
cards.definition: Stimulus-Based Definition of Stress

cards.term: Response-Based Definition of Stress
cards.definition: Emphasizes the physiological responses (e.g., increased arousal) that occur when faced with demanding situations.

cards.term: Emphasizes the physiological responses (e.g., increased arousal) that occur when faced with demanding situations.
cards.definition: Response-Based Definition of Stress

cards.term: Primary Appraisal (Lazarus & Folkman)
cards.definition: Judgment about the degree of potential harm or threat to well-being that a stressor might entail.

cards.term: Judgment about the degree of potential harm or threat to well-being that a stressor might entail.
cards.definition: Primary Appraisal (Lazarus & Folkman)

cards.term: General Adaptation Syndrome (Selye)
cards.definition: The body's nonspecific physiological response to stress. Consists of three stages: Alarm Reaction, Resistance, and Exhaustion.

cards.term: The body's nonspecific physiological response to stress. Consists of three stages: Alarm Reaction, Resistance, and Exhaustion.
cards.definition: General Adaptation Syndrome (Selye)

cards.term: HPA Axis
cards.definition: The Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal axis. A set of structures found in both the limbic system (hypothalamus) and the endocrine system (pituitary and adrenal glands) that regulate many of the body's physiological reactions to stress through the release of hormones like cortisol.

cards.term: The Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal axis. A set of structures found in both the limbic system (hypothalamus) and the endocrine system (pituitary and adrenal glands) that regulate many of the body's physiological reactions to stress through the release of hormones like cortisol.
cards.definition: HPA Axis

cards.term: Type A Behavior Pattern
cards.definition: Characterized by an excessive competitive drive, chronic sense of time urgency, impatience, and hostility toward others (particularly hostility is linked to heart disease).

cards.term: Characterized by an excessive competitive drive, chronic sense of time urgency, impatience, and hostility toward others (particularly hostility is linked to heart disease).
cards.definition: Type A Behavior Pattern

cards.term: Problem-Focused Coping
cards.definition: Managing or altering the problem that is causing one to experience stress (e.g., identifying the problem, weighing solutions).

cards.term: Managing or altering the problem that is causing one to experience stress (e.g., identifying the problem, weighing solutions).
cards.definition: Problem-Focused Coping

cards.term: Emotion-Focused Coping
cards.definition: Efforts to change or reduce the negative emotions associated with stress (e.g., avoiding, minimizing, distancing).

cards.term: Efforts to change or reduce the negative emotions associated with stress (e.g., avoiding, minimizing, distancing).
cards.definition: Emotion-Focused Coping
